title: 108_hr2801
content: The Act titled "Minority Serving Institution Digital and Wireless Technology Opportunity Act of 2003" establishes a program. The Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 is amended to establish the Minority Serving Institution Digital and Wireless Technology Opportunity Program. This program aims to assist eligible institutions in acquiring digital and wireless networking technologies to enhance educational services. Eligible institutions can use grants for equipment, networking capability, and software. The Minority Serving Institution Digital and Wireless Technology Opportunity Program aims to enhance educational services by providing networking technology, training programs, and professional development for teachers and individuals seeking to improve technology skills. The Minority Serving Institution Digital and Wireless Technology Opportunity Program aims to enhance educational services by providing networking technology, training programs, and professional development for teachers and individuals seeking to improve technology skills. The program supports acquiring or enhancing technology skills, obtaining capacity-building technical assistance, and fostering the use of digital and wireless networking technology to improve research and education in various fields. Eligible institutions must follow application and review procedures to receive grants, cooperative agreements, or contracts under this program. Eligible institutions must submit an application to the Under Secretary detailing how funds will be used for digital and wireless networking technology, ensuring accessibility for students, faculty, and administrators. The Under Secretary, in consultation with an advisory council, will establish review procedures for these applications. The Under Secretary will establish review procedures for applications from eligible institutions seeking funds for digital and wireless networking technology. An advisory council will be formed to provide guidance on maximizing participation and reviewing proposals for the program. The Under Secretary will establish an advisory council with representatives from minority businesses and experts in digital and wireless networking technology. Review panels will assess the quality and merit of proposals from eligible institutions for utilizing grants, cooperative agreements, or contracts for the program. The Under Secretary will ensure that review panels for the program include representatives from minority serving institutions and individuals knowledgeable about eligible institutions and technology issues. Conflict of interest will be avoided in the review process, and recommendations from the panel will be considered in awarding grants, cooperative agreements, or contracts. An annual meeting of eligible institutions will be convened for information dissemination. The Secretary will convene an annual meeting of eligible institutions receiving grants, agreements, or contracts to promote collaboration and capacity-building activities. Eligible institutions must agree to a matching requirement for costs incurred in carrying out the program. The Under Secretary requires donations from public or private entities, with non-Federal contributions equal to one-quarter of the grant amount or $500,000, whichever is less. The matching requirement is waived for institutions with no endowment or an endowment below $50,000,000. Institutions receiving over $2,500,000 in funding are not eligible for additional grants, agreements, or contracts. The Under Secretary may provide grants, cooperative agreements, or contracts to eligible institutions for consortia involving various entities such as State agencies, education institutions, and businesses, including minority businesses. Funding may also be provided for planning grants. The Under Secretary may provide funds for strategic plans to implement grants, agreements, or contracts to eligible institutions, ensuring diversity in awards and prioritizing institutions with the greatest need. Annual reports and evaluations are required. Annual reports are required from institutions receiving grants, agreements, or contracts under this subsection. An independent assessment by the National Academy of Public Administration will be conducted every 3 years. The assessments, conducted every 3 years, evaluate the effectiveness of the program in improving education, training, access to digital technology at eligible institutions. The National Academy of Public Administration evaluates procedures and makes recommendations for improving the program, including the need for Federal support. The Under Secretary transmits assessments to Congress along with plans to implement recommendations. In this subsection, definitions are provided for "digital and wireless networking technology" and "eligible institution," including historically Black colleges or universities that are part B institutions under the Higher Education Act of 1965.
